quiz.title: Unit 4: Forces (Quiz 2)
quiz.subtitle: Newton's Second Law and Force Applications (20 Questions)
quiz.subject: Physics
quiz.topic: F=ma Calculations, Weight, and Real-World Applications

questions.question: Which is an example of a non-contact force?
options: A book resting on a table
A car tire on the road
questions.explanation: Magnetic force can act at a distance without physical contact.

questions.question: If the net force on an object is zero, the object must be:
options: Either at rest or moving at constant velocity
questions.explanation: Zero net force means no acceleration, so the object could be at rest OR moving at constant velocity.

questions.question: A 1,200 kg car accelerates at 2 m/s². What net force is required?
What is required to change an object's state of motion?
questions.explanation: A net external force is required to change an object's motion (accelerate it).

questions.question: A person pushes a box with 50 N east while friction acts with 15 N west. What is the net force?
questions.explanation: 50 N east - 15 N west = 35 N east.

questions.question: Which has more inertia: a loaded truck or the same truck when empty?
questions.explanation: The loaded truck has more mass, therefore more inertia.

questions.question: If you double the net force on an object, what happens to its acceleration?
questions.explanation: From F = ma, if mass is constant and F doubles, acceleration must double.

questions.question: A 0.5 kg ball is thrown with a force of 20 N. What is its acceleration?
Why do passengers lurch forward when a bus suddenly stops?
questions.explanation: Inertia causes passengers to continue moving forward when the bus stops suddenly.

questions.question: Three forces act on an object: 10 N north, 10 N south, and 5 N east. What is the net force?
questions.explanation: North and south forces cancel (10 N - 10 N = 0), leaving only 5 N east.

questions.question: What mass would accelerate at 4 m/s² under a 20 N force?
questions.explanation: m = F/a = 20 N / 4 m/s² = 5 kg.

questions.question: Which force keeps planets in orbit around the sun?
questions.explanation: Gravity is the attractive force between masses that keeps planets in orbit.

questions.question: A hockey puck slides across frictionless ice. What is the net force on it?
options: Equal to the push that started it
questions.explanation: No friction means no net force, so it continues at constant velocity (Newton's First Law).

questions.question: If mass is constant and net force triples, what happens to acceleration?
questions.explanation: From a = F/m, if F triples and m is constant, acceleration triples.

questions.question: What is the weight of a 60 kg person on Earth? (g = 9.8 m/s²)
questions.explanation: Weight = mg = 60 kg × 9.8 m/s² = 588 N.

questions.question: A book rests on a table. Why doesn't it accelerate downward due to gravity?
options: Gravity stops acting on stationary objects
The table pushes up with equal force
questions.explanation: The normal force from the table balances gravity, resulting in zero net force.

questions.question: A net force of 15 N acts on a 3 kg object. After 4 seconds, how much has its velocity changed?
questions.explanation: a = F/m = 15 N / 3 kg = 5 m/s². Δv = a × t = 5 m/s² × 4 s = 20 m/s.

questions.question: Which requires more force to accelerate: a bicycle or a car?
questions.explanation: The car has more mass, so according to F = ma, it requires more force for the same acceleration.

questions.question: A 500 g object accelerates at 6 m/s². What net force acts on it?
What is the net force on a falling object at terminal velocity?
questions.explanation: At terminal velocity, air resistance equals weight, so net force is zero and acceleration stops.

scoreMessages.70: Very Good! You understand most concepts but should review weight calculations and terminal velocity.
scoreMessages.50: Good effort! Focus on practicing F=ma problems in various contexts.
